For referencing two or more things from multiple "sources"
Example:
https://conworkshop.com/translation.php?s=3bdb6678655d3ad7eef2f6fe57ab2123&l=EOO
In the above translation, nôeá references all the ideas and all the viruses, "sourced" from the subject and object respectively of the previous clause.

All _s
Must be used with a paucal or plural noun

Applies to the subject, somewhat in relation to other subjects.
E.g., I am happy, you are also happy

Applies to the object relative to things which are different from the object.
This is a terrible description, so here is an example: using this definition of "also", the sentence "I also have three boats" means that you have three boats in addition to some other (typically previously mentioned) things.

Applies to the object relative to things which are the same as the object.
This is a terrible description, so here is an example: using this definition of "also", the sentence "I also have three boats" means that you have three boats in addition to some other unspecified amount of boats.
An amount contained, somewhat like the "ful" in "handful"

Connects only nominal phrases (nouns/pronouns/etc). The first word is more important or better, faster, etc.

Examples:
Iá enêi ió oàn án îné.
/1S.AN and 2S.AN fast thing.PAU.AN be.PRES.1/
This means that the speaker and listener are both fast, but that the speaker is faster.
Iá áo'énó'a enêi ôenáó'a á'îá.
/1S.AN apple.PL.AN and banana.PL.AN like.PRES.1/
This means that the speaker likes both apples and bananas, but likes apples more.

Indicates some relation between two clauses, somewhat like the left-hand clause being "fed into" the right-hand clause
For an example, see https://conworkshop.com/translation.php?s=941177395641832896743ab6790906cf&l=EOO

column6:
"Nôn", a future form of this verb, can also be "noôn" or "no'ôn"; the latter of these alternate forms is sometimes used to prevent confusion with the words nôn (two) and noôn (four).

These alternate forms can also appear following a conjugative particle (NEG/2/3/etc.), so that, for example, "é nôn" ("you will imply") can also be "é noôn" or "é no'ôn" (although "noôn" and "no'ôn" are much rarer when preceded by such a particle, as the potential for confusion is lower).

column6: Hundreds or thousands of years old
Applies to the subject, e.g. "Only I know"

Applies to the object relative to everything else
For example, "You only see the tree" means that you see nothing at all other than the tree.
See also https://conworkshop.com/word.php?w=52f35797f2a8683db03be2312e835083

Applies to the object relative to things which are the same as the object
This is a terrible description, so here is an example: using this definition of "only", the sentence "I only have ten fingers" means that the number of fingers you have is equal to ten, but it does not mean that you have nothing at all other than your ten fingers.
See also https://conworkshop.com/word.php?w=12347144eb35b6231b3e90e1f5917d9c

Do nothing else
E.g., saying that you only eat would mean that you do nothing other than eating (possibly other than living/breathing).
Saying that A and B only eat would mean that A and B eat together but do nothing else together (again, possibly excepting living/breathing).
Expresses a limit, e.g. "I can only count to four" means that the speaker cannot count past the number four (but can still count up to 3)
E.g., energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can only be converted from one form to another

Applies to a noun relative to everything else.
For example, "Only you see the tree" means that nobody and nothing other than you sees the tree.
Also for things without lids or hinges (e.g. to open a coconut)

E.g., "Would you like small, medium, or large?"
Inclusive or; implies that more than one option can be chosen

E.g., "Would you like small, medium, or large?"
Exclusive or; implies that only one option can be chosen
E.g., the order of the letters in the alphabet

Typically takes the lowest animacy of the two members of the pair.
For example:
    - A pair of two people would be animate
    - A pair of one living person and one dead person would be deceased
    - A pair of two rocks would be inanimate
    - A pair of a living person and a rock would be inanimate
etc.

Referring to something which seems random to you, but is actually there for a reason. For example, you might call somebody who you don't know a "random person" in English, or you might say that there is "random junk" in your attic. In both cases, there is or was a conscious agent at work, and the person and the junk are thus not actually random, so you would use the word neà'óé in Eo'iona.
Refers to something which is actually random, as opposed to neà'óé.

column6:
"Be been on by"
For example, if moss is on a rock, then the rock is been on by the moss. This verb is similar to "be on", but with the subject and object in each other's places, as shown in the example.
Strictly physical, as opposed to being on drugs, on the television, etc.
If this verb is used without an object, it means "be been on", by nothing specific.

A gap is an open or empty space in or between things. This word refers to one of those things. It is often pascal or plural.
